trial_identification.studytitle: Fractures of the distal radius: a randomized controlled trial of 180 patients comparing volar locking plates and traditional surgical treatment
trial_identification.scientifictitle: In treating patients with distal radius fractures, do volar locking plates produce better outcomes than traditional surgical treatment when assessed by DASH score primarily with function and radiological assessment as secondary outcomes.

interventions.interventions: Volar locking plate fixation of distal radius fracture. Surgery involves a volar approach to the distal radius and fixation with a plate which utilises locking screw heads. This is designed to provide a stable construct, supporting the chondral surface and allowing early mobilisation. Surgery takes about an hour.
interventions.comparator: Surgical treatment of distal radius fractures other than Volar Locking Plate, including Kirschner wires, non-locking plates and external fixateur. Choice of which surgical procedure in this group is at the discretion of the treating physician but excludes Volar Locking Plate.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: One week post surgery, 12 weeks, 52 weeks.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Range of motion of the affected wrist, both actual range and as a percentage of the unaffected wrist motion, measured with a goniometer placed at the axis of wrist motion and measured in three planes.
Grip strength measured with a Jamar Dynamometer and averaged over three readings, recorded in kilograms and expressed as a percentage of the uninjured side.
Radiological measurement, radial length, angle, inclination and step
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Initial, in theatre, one, 6, 12 weeks post operation.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Patients with a distal radius fracture requiring surgical fixation, over 18 years old.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Cognitive incapacity, neurological disorders affecting coordination or function, pre-existing upper limb deformity or disability and concurrent upper limb injury.
